sentence-detokenized: EU rejects German call for boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday that it disagrees with Germany's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative to the European Union's veterinary committee Werner Zwingmann said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than the UK until scientific opinion is clearer.
"We do not support any such recommendation because we see no basis for it," - Commission chief spokesman Nikolaus van der Pas said at a press briefing.
He said further research was needed, and if it was found that action was needed, it should be taken by the European Union.

He said last month's proposal by EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords from human and animal food chains was a very concrete and precautionary move to protect human health.
Fischler proposed the pan-European measures after reports from the UK and France that sheep can contract bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease - under laboratory conditions.

But Fischler agreed to revise his proposal after the EU's standing veterinary committee, mational animal health officials, questioned whether such action was justified, as there was only a small risk to human health.
Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio had earlier accused Fischler at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers of causing unwarranted alarm by making "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's scientific veterinary and multidisciplinary committees are due to re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to contract scrapie, a brain-death disease similar to BSE, which is believed to have been transmitted to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that there was any risk to human health from their sheep, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"What we need to be extremely wary of is how other countries are going to take the example of Germany," - Welsh National Farmers' Union (NFU) president John Lloyd Jones told BBC radio.

Bonn is leading the drive to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March after a UK report suggested that people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47 600 sheep from the UK last year, accounting for almost half of all imports.
It imported 4,275 tonnes of British mutton, around 10 per cent of all imports.
A rare sketch of a Hendrix song sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare early handwritten sketch of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix was sold on Thursday for almost $17,000 at an auction of the late musician's favourite items.
The Florida-based restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for a sketch of 'Ain't No Telling', which Hendrix wrote on a piece of London hotel stationery in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in January 1967 in the English city of Nottingham, he threw a card into the audience, where it was retrieved by a fan.
Buyers also snapped up 16 other items auctioned by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
Among them was a black lacquer and mother-of-pearl-encrusted box used by Hendrix to store medication, which an anonymous Australian buyer bought for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China accused Taipei on Thursday of spoiling the atmosphere for the resumption of cross-Strait talks with a visit to Ukraine by Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan this week, which angered Beijing.

Speaking just hours after Chinese state media said the time was right for political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters, "The atmosphere necessary for the opening of talks has been disrupted by Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's chief negotiator in Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a group visiting Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to engage in political talks....
that is, to end the state of hostility, "Thursday's overseas edition of People's Daily quoted Tang as saying.

Shen of the foreign ministry said in an interview with Reuters television that he had read reports of Tang's comments, but did not give details of why the negotiator felt the time was right for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed any effort by Taipei to gain greater international recognition, was angered by Taiwanese Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says the time is right to talk about Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said that it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps in this direction.

Consultations should be held to determine the timing and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency reported on Wednesday, quoting Tang Shubei, vice-president of the Association for Cross-Strait Relations.
German car registrations in July rose by 14.2pc year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
German first motor vehicle registrations rose by 14.2 per cent in July this year compared to the year-earlier period, the Federal Office for Motor Vehicles reported on Thursday.
The bureau said that 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 -- 304,850 cars and 15,613 trucks.
The figures represent an increase of 13.6 per cent for cars and a decrease of 2.2 per cent for trucks compared to July 1995.
Motorbike registrations increased by 32.7 per cent over the period.
The increase was partly due to an increased number of Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, the federal office said.
Almost all German carmakers recorded an increase in registrations during this period.
Volkswagen AG won 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of the total.
Opel AG, together with General Motors, took second place with 49,269 registrations, representing 16.4 per cent of the total.
Third was Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7 per cent.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 registrations in July a year earlier.
Porsche registrations fell to 554 from 643.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE GREEN LIGHT TO PM FOR ELECTIONS.
The presidium of the Greek Socialist Party has given the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call elections, General Secretary Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after the cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.

Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appear to be a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador to Washington led the fruitless negotiations with Syria, told Israeli radio that it appears that Damascus wants to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that the {(1)[MISC] Syrian priority} is still negotiations.
The Syrians are confused, they are definitely tense, but the overall assessment here in Washington is that it's basically a storm in a teacup, "he said.
Rabinovich is completing his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician of the right-wing Likud party.
Israel sent Syria a message on Wednesday, via Washington, saying it is committed to peace and wants to open negotiations without preconditions.
But she condemned Damascus for creating what she called a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria accused Israel on Wednesday of unleashing a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a rocket.
It said its arms purchases were for defensive purposes.

"The message we sent to (Syrian President Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready at any time without preconditions to enter into peace negotiations," - Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israeli radio.
Tensions have risen since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June, vowing to preserve the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan have remained deadlocked since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming out of Damascus are bad, not good.
Media...
are full of expressions and declarations that must cause concern....
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners, "said Levy.
"We expect Syria, if its face is peace, to respond to Israel's message to enter into peace negotiations, because that is our goal," - he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
No one gains from wars. "
Israel's Channel Two television said that Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
It did not provide any source for this report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm this.
The TV channel also reported that Netanyahu had sent messages to reassure Syria through Cairo, the US and Moscow.
A Polish diplomat denies that the nurses are stuck in Libya.

A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a Polish tabloid's report this week that Libya had denied exit visas to 100 Polish nurses trying to return to the country after working in the North African state.
"This is not true.

To date, we have no knowledge of any nurse imprisoned or detained in Libya without her will and we have not received any complaint," - Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, charge d'affaires of the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

The Polish labour ministry said this week that it would send a team to Libya to investigate the case, but Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by some nurses complaining about working conditions, such as not being paid their salaries.
He said there are an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq vowed on Thursday to extend support to Iranian Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian troops deep inside Iraq last month.

A statement from the Mujahideen Khalq organisation said its leader Massoud Rajavi met with Democratic Kurdistan Party (KDPI) General Secretary Hassan Rastegar in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed support for the Iranian Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to stand shoulder-to-shoulder with its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance in Iranian Kurdistan," it wrote.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between Mujahideen Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
Iran intensively bombed targets in northern Iraq in July as part of its pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside government control in Baghdad.
Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of guerrillas of the Iraqi Kurdish group Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).

The PUK and the Iraqi Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), the two main Iraqi Kurdish factions, have had northern Iraq under their control since the ouster of Iraqi forces from Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two sides erupted over the weekend in the most serious fighting since a US-sponsored ceasefire last year.
Mujahideen Khalq said that Iranian troops have also been shelling KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniya province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
It reported that around 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are carrying out air and ground attacks on targets in northern Iraq, pursuing their own Kurdish rebels.
The US-led air force in southern Turkey is protecting Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by troops from Baghdad.
Saudi riyal exchange rate stable in quiet summer trade.
The Saudi riyal spot against the dollar and riyal interbank deposit rates were mostly stable this week in quiet summer trading, dealers in the kingdom said.
"There has been no change in the Saudi riyal exchange rates.
The market was very quiet because of the holidays, "said one dealer.
Spot riyal was put at 3.7504 / 06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8 per cent, three-month deposits were at 5-5/8, 1/2 per cent and six-month deposits were at 5-3/4, 5/8 per cent.
One-year funds were at six, 5-7/8 per cent.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory to the West Bank on Thursday, ending a brief Israeli-Palestinian crisis, an Arafat adviser said.
"The problem is over.
The president's plane has been allowed to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank before Monday, "Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the venue was changed to Gaza after Israel refused to allow the Palestinian leader's helicopters to fly over.
Palestinian officials have accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on the ground.
Arafat then cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials, on civil affairs, at the Allenby Bridge crossing between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday, after Israel lifted the ban, because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be off until Monday.
Arafat will meet Peres in Gaza after the air ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in the Gaza Strip on Thursday, after Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government barred the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japan's Finance Minister Wataru Kubo told a press conference on Wednesday that he believes the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is geared towards ensuring economic growth, has not changed following the central bank's 'tankan' survey.
